name: Admiral
notes:
Bittering hops derived from Wye Challenger.  Good high-alpha bittering hops.
Used for: Ales
Aroma: Primarily for bittering
Substitutes: Target, Northdown, Challenger

name: African Queen
notes: A high alpha hop from South Africa with interesting bittering potential and fruity flavors.  Fruity aroma includes hints of blueberry, cassis, passion fruit, citrus, stone fruit, black currant, tea, lemongrass and even chili.  Can be used both for bittering and as a late addition.

name: Agnus
notes:
Several large Czech breweries like Agnus as a bittering hop because its alpha/beta ratio is relatively high, which they believe makes their beer more stable. High geraniol level, oils indicate dry hopping potential.
Used for: Ales
Aroma: Strong hop aroma, spicy
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
9-15% AA / 4-8% Beta

name: Ahtanum
notes:
Distinctive aromatic hops with moderate bittering power from Washington.
Used for: American ales and lagers
Aroma: Distinctive floral and citrus aromas
Substitutes: Amarillo, Cascade

name: Amallia
notes: A native plant from New Mexico and part of the neomexicana varietal.  Trialed by Michigan State University in 2014. A deeply earthy aroma with flavors of orange citrus. Well suited for brown or dark ales.

name: Amarillo
notes:
Discovered and introduced by Vigil Gamache Farms Inc. in Washington State. Character similar to Cascade.  Often used as a late kettle or dry hop addition to American style Pale Ales and IPA’s due to its signature aroma characteristics. Used for both bitterness and aroma.
Used for: IPAs, Ales
Aroma: Intensely fruity (citrus, melon, and stone friuts), floral, tropical notes.
Substitutes: Cascade, Centennial, Simcoe
Storage: Good
8-11% AA / 6-7% Beta

name: Amarillo Gold
notes:
Unknown origin, but character similar to Cascade.  Used for both bitterness and aroma.
Used for: IPAs, Ales
Aroma: Citrus, flowery
Substitutes: Cascade, Centennial

name: Amethyst
notes: Low alpha aroma hops related to saaz grown in the Czech Republic. Citrusy, earthly and spicy.  Substitutes: Saaz

name: Aquila
notes:
Aroma hops developed in 1988.  Limited use due to high cohumolone.
Used for: Aroma hops
Substitutes: Cluster
No longer commercially grown.

name: Apollo
notes:
Super high alpha variety from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006.  High alpha and low cohumulone makes it a great bittering hop. Adds a strong grapefruit/hop note if added late in boil.
Used for: IPA, IIPA
Aroma: Strong grapefruit and hoppy notes
Substitutes: Nugget, CTZ, Bravo
Storage: Excellent/Very Good (80-90% AA remaining after 6 months at 20 C)
15-19% AA / 5.5-8% Beta

name: Apolon
notes: A Slovenian hybrid that is a cross between Brewer's Gold and a Yugoslavian wild male.  Once thought to be related to Super Styrian.  Traditionally bred for bittering can also be used as an aroma hop.

name: Aramis
notes:
Very fine spice and herbal notes with subtle citrus characteristics. Closely resembling Strisselspalt, but with higher oil and alpha content.

Used for: Belgian-style Ales
Substitutions: Willamette, Challenger, Ahtanum
Storage: Unknown

name: Archer
notes: A new variety from the Charles Faram Hop program.  Classic British aroma with a citrus twist.  Aroma is floral with delicate hints of lime and peach.  Provides traditional British assertiveness.

name: Ariana
notes: Developed at the hop research center in Hull, Germany.  A cross between Hurkules and a wild male.  Aromas include black currant, grapefruit, gooseberry, geranium and vanilla.

name: Atlas
notes:
A cross between Brewers Gold and Slovenian wild hops.  Primarily a bittering hop with pleasant bitterness and aroma.  
Used for: Bittering ales, lagers  
Substitutes: Brewers Gold

name: Atlas (Styrian Atlas)
notes:
A cross between Brewers Gold and Slovenian wild hops.  Primarily a bittering hop with pleasant bitterness and aroma.  
Used for: Bittering ales, lagers
Aroma: Fresh hoppy aroma
Substitutes: Brewers Gold
Storage: Very Good
7-11% AA / 3.2-41% Beta

name: Aurora
notes:
Also called Super Styrian.  This is a hybrid between Northern Brewer and TG.  It has a pleasant hoppy aroma similar to Styrian Goldings but lighter.  
Used for: Often mixed with other hops in lagers.  
Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

name: Aurora (Super Styrian Aurora)
notes:
Also called Super Styrian Aurora.  This is a hybrid between Northern Brewer and TG.  Pleasant hoppy aroma similar to Styrian Golding but lighter.
Used for: Strong Ale, Pale Ale, Bitter
Aroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma
Substitutes: Styrian Golding
Storage: Excellent/Very Good (80-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
7-9% AA/ 3-5% Beta

name: Azacca
notes:
Notes: Dual purpose hop. Good for dry hopping
Aroma: Citrus, tropical, floral

name: Banner
notes:
Bittering hops developed in 1988.  Use largely discontinued due to poor storage.
Used for: U.S. style ales
Substitutes: Cluster

name: Beata Hops
notes: Beata is a low alpha British aromatic hop developed at Wye College in the UK in 1995 though it did not go into production until 2006.  Lovely aroma, with classic British complexity.  High beta levels also contribute unique properties.  Honey, apricot and almond notes.

name: Belma
notes:
New variety produced at Puterbaugh Farms. First introduced to public Fall 2012.
Used for: Expedrimental Ales and Lagers
Aroma: A very clean hop, with a very orange, slight grapefruit, tropical (but not mango/guava, more like pineapple), strawberry, and melon
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
9.8% AA / ??% Beta (5 year avg not yet established)

name: Bitter Gold
notes:
Intense stone fruit especially pear and watermellon. A super-alpha variety with excellent aroma.

Used for: All Styles
Substitutions: Galena, Nugget

name: Boadicea
notes:
Released in 2004. Excellent for finishing and dry hopping.
Used for: Ales
Aroma: Mild floral and spicy characteristics with slightly grassy overtones
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
7-10% AA / 3-4% Beta

name: Bobek (Styrian Golding B)
notes:
Also called Styrian Golding B - a cross between Northern Brewer and a TG seedling.
Used for: English Ales, ESB, Lagers, Pilsners
Aroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma
Substitutes: Northern Brewer,  Styrian Golding, UK or US Fuggle, Willamette
Storage: Unknown
3.5-7% AA / 4-6.1% Beta

name: Bravo
notes:
A second generation super high alpha hops from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006.  Good bittering hop.
Aroma: Fruity and floral aroma.
Substitutes: Columbus, Zeus, Tomahawk

name: Bouclier
notes: A cross between Alsace grown Strisselspalt and a wild male plant from Wye, Kent.  Grassy with hints of spice.  Aromas of herbs, grass, spice with some floral and citrus character.

name: Brewer's Gold, Germany
notes:
Black currant, fruit and spice characteristics. Has a high resin content and gives a well-balanced bitterness which is ideally complimented by late hop additions in lager beers.

Usage: Ale, Bière de Garde, Lambic, Lager, Saison
Substitutions: Galena, Northdown, Northern Brewer
Storage: Unknown

name: Brewer's Gold, UK
notes:
Brewers Gold is a complex bittering hop that is noted to have a sharp or pungent bittering quality. It also imparts a fruity yet spicy aroma as well as having a black currant characteristic. It is on the low end of the bittering hop scale at 8 to 10% AAU typically. Brewers Gold can be used in a wide range of styles from English Ales to German Lagers and adds a decidely 'European' element to the beer. These make a good partner to noble varieties such as Tettnang and Hallertauer.

Used for: English Ale, German Lagers
Substitutions: Bullion, Chinook, Galena

name: Brooklyn
notes:
A high alpha hop with distinctive tropical, grapefruit and passion fruit characters. Developed from Southern Cross.

Used for: IPAs
Substitutions: N/A

name: Bullion
notes:
A major hop variety since the mid-1940s, however, product ceased in 1985 due to super alpha hops with better storage stability. Commonly used in darker beers.
Used for: Stouts, ESB, Scotch Ale, IPA, Porter, Heavy German lagers.
Aroma: Strong, pungent and bitter in flavor. Intense Black currant aroma.
Substitutes: Chinook, Galena, Eroica, Columbus, Northern Brewer (German), Brewer's Gold (German).
Storage: Poor (40%-50% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
6.5-9% AA / 3.2-6% Beta

name: Bullion
notes:
Used in strong dark English ales, some heavy German lagers.
Aroma: Strong, pungent and bitter in flavor.  Blackcurrant flavor.
Substitutes: Chinook, Eroica, Brewer's Gold

name: CTZ Hop Hash
notes:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

Columbus, Tomahawk and Zeus are collectively called CTZ and are similar in character and often blended.  They provide citrus aromas, black peper, licorace and curry notes.

name: Calicross
notes: New Zealand Calicross was developed in the 1960's and largely disappeared in the 1980s.  Can still occasionally be found.  A cross between Fuggle and Late Cluster.  Earthy, fruity flavors with floral aromas.  Substitute: Cluster

name: Calypso
notes:
A new, dual-purpose hop from the Hopsteiner breeding program that may establish itself as "special".
Used for: Ales, Stouts and Barley Wines
Aroma: Not as tropical as the name might imply but rich in both stone fruits (pear and peaches, notes of cherry) and citrus.
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Good (65-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
12-14% AA / 5-6% Beta

name: Canadian Redvine
notes: From Canada and very disease resistant.  It has a very high cohumulone content and low alpha making it a good late hop candidate.  Aroma and flavor of berries, pine, cherry and grapefruit peel.

name: Cascade
notes:
A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage
Used for: American ales and lagers
Aroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefruit character
Substitutes: Centennial
Examples: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale

name: Cascade Hop Extract
notes:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Made from Cascade hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Cascade, New Zealand
notes:
Flowers, citrus & spice with grapefruit the noticeable fragrance quite often. This medium aroma balances the low bittering value. Very popular hop among craft brewers.

Used for: Pale Ales, IPAs, Porters
Substitutions: Centennial, Amarillo

name: Cashmere
notes:
Daughter of Cascade. Mild herbal aroma with strong melon, lemon, and slightly spicy notes.

Used for: American Pale Ale, IPA
Substitutions: N/A

name: Bobek
notes:
Also called Styrian Golding B - a cross between Northern Brewer and a TG seedling.  Pleasant hop aroma and flavor.  
Used for: Moderate English ales and lagers/Pilsners 
Substitutes: Northern Brewer

name: Celeia
notes:
A dual purpose hops that is a hybrid between Savinjski Golding, Aurora and Slovenian wild hops.  Similar in aroma to Saaz.  
Used for: Light lagers, Pilsners, Belgian ales.
Substitutes: Saaz, Styrian Goldings

name: Centennial
notes:
Used for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats
Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavor
Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion
Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

name: Centennial Hop Extract
notes:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Centennial hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Centennial Hop Hash
notes:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

Columbus, Tomahawk and Zeus are collectively called CTZ and are similar in character and often blended.  They provide citrus aromas, black peper, licorace and curry notes.

name: Challenger
notes:
Variant of Northern Brewers heritage
Used for: Both aroma and bittering for ales and lagers
Aroma: Fruity in flavor, spicy aroma, blends well
Substitutes: N/A

name: Chelan
notes:
High alpha variety from the Haas breeding program released in 2004.  It is a variant of Galena and very similar in profile to Galena.
Aroma: Pleasant citrus notes  
Substitutes: Galena

name: Chinook
notes:
Strong versatile bittering hop
Used for: Ales, porters, stouts
Aroma: Heavy and spicy aroma
Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion
Examples: Sierra Nevada Stout, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale

name: Chinook Hop Extract
notes:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Centennial hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Chinook, New Zealand
notes:
Piney with exotic spice and infused with grapefruit. This alluring aroma and a high bittering value has gained this hop full respect from craft & major brewers.

Used for: American Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, Stout
Substitutions: Southern Cross, Sticklebract, Nugget, Northern Brewer

name: Citra
notes:
Special aroma hops released in 2007.  Imparts high alpha/oil content but low cohumulone.
Aroma: Adds interesting citrus and tropical fruit character to the beer.  
Substitutes: Unknown

name: Citra Hop Extract
notes:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Citra hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Cluster
notes:
Used for: General purpose bittering hop
Aroma: Floral, slightly spicy. Sharp aroma and sharp flavor
Substitutes: Eroica, Galena

name: Columbia
notes:
Sibling of Williamette hops.
Used for: All English Ales
Aroma: Close to Fuggles
Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

name: Columbus (Tomahawk)
notes:
Engineered Centennial Substitute - High alpha bittering hops.
Used for: Bittering, flavor, aroma - IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, Lager
Aroma: Pungent, spicy. Strongly aromatic, but clean tasting bitterness
Substitutes: Centennial

name: Columbus/Tomahawk/Zeus (CTZ)
notes:
Engineered Centennial Substitute - High alpha bittering hops.
Used for: IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, Lager, Barley Wine
Aroma: Pungent, spicy. Strongly aromatic, but clean tasting bitterness
Substitutes: Other CTZ, Galena, Chinook, Nugget, Target (U.K.), Northern Brewer (Germany)
Storage: Poor/Very Poor (45-65% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
14-16.5% AA / 4-5% Beta

name: Comet
notes:
Very bitter hops - use sparingly with other hops
Used for: Bittering only
Substitutes: N/A

name: Cryo - Cascade
notes: A classic Pacific NW Hops - floral, citrusy, prized in IPAs.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the weight of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Cryo - Eukanot
notes: An aromatic hop with some tropical, citrus, fruity, and herbal notes.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the weight of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils.  Store near freezing.

name: Cryo - Citra
notes: Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the weight of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Cryo - Loral
notes: Loral is a floral, citrus, fruity, herbal hops used for its aromatic qualities.  Versatile.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the weight of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Cryo - Mosaic
notes: Mosaic is an earthy, floral, fruity hops widely used for finishing IPAs.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the weight of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Cryo - Palisade
notes: A earthy, floral, fruity hop used for aroma including apricot, grass and floral components. Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the weight of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Cryo - Simcoe
notes: An earthly, citrus, pine hop widely used in IPAs and many American styles.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the weight of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Crystal
notes:
Used for: Aroma and finishing hops for Lagers
Aroma: Clean, mild, pleasant and slightly spicy
Substitutes: Hallertauer, Mount Liberty

name: Dana
notes: Also known as "Extra Styrian Dana" this is a Slovenian hop breed crossing a wild Slovenian male plant with German Magnum.  It has smooth bittering properties and a slightly citrus and floral aroma profile.

name: Defender
notes: Bred from a New Mexico wild female and Eastwell Golding male at Wye College, England.  Low alpha and yield has limited acreage.  A pleasant European style aroma.

name: Delta
notes:
A backcross between Fuggles and Cascade, recently released (2012) by the Hopsteiner breeding program. Woody and herbal with a citrus kick. Not as assertive as dual purpose hops but adds distinctive notes in a blend.
Used for: IPA, Pale Ale
Aroma: Mild and pleasant aroma; slightly spicy with a hint of citrus.
Substitutions: Fuggle, Willamette
Storage: Excellent (80-90% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
5-7% AA / 5-7% Beta

name: Denali (Exp 06277)
notes: Formerly hopsteiner experimental #06227.  Denali is a high alpha aroma hop with heritage to Zeus and Nugget as well as a USDA male.  It has a big aroma including pineapple, citrus and pine notes.  High essential oil content makes it suitable for dry hopping or whirlpool additions such as IPAs.

name: Dr. Rudi
notes:
A dual purpose / bittering hop with classic resinous pine and lifted citrus characters.

Used for: Ales
Substitutions: N/A

name: East Kent Goldings (EKG)
notes:
Also known as Canterbury Hops by some, although others will dispute this fact. East Kent Goldings gracefully defines the English Pale Ales and Ales produced by the region, it is quintessentially English.
Used for: English Ale, Porter, Scottish and Irish Ale, Stout, Strong Ale, ESB, Saison, Barleywine.
Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor
Substitutes: First Gold, Fuggles, other Golding varieties, Progress, Target, and Whitbread Golding
Storage: Good/Fair 965-80% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
4-7% AA / 1.9-2.8% Beta

name: El Dorado
notes:
Bred by CLS Farms, LLC, available on a larger scale for the first time during 2012 harvest. Fits the dual purpose/special mold.
Used for: Experimental Ales
Aroma: Tropical fruit flavors, intense aromas of stone fruits (pear, cherries), candy (Lifesavers), watermelon.
Substitutions: None at this time
Storage: Good
14-16% AA / 7-8% Beta

name: El Dorado Hop Extract
notes:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from El Dorado hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: El Dorado Hop Hash
notes:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

El Dorado brings forward some tropical fruit flavors of pear, watermelon and stone fruit.

name: Ella
notes: Ella was formerly known as Stella.  Its an Australian variety that is a half sister to Galaxy and related to Spalt.  It was released in 2007 for trials and became quite popular.  Ella has a very high aromatic oil content that changes depending on how its used.  In small quantities it provides a spicy, floral quality like star anise.  Larger quantities or dry hopping provide more of a tropical or grapefruit flavor.

name: Ella (aka Stella)
notes:
New name after a 2013 harvest in Australia (due to name infringement). Despite high alpha, sold as an aroma variety. When used in dry hopping or higher quantities, grapefruit and tropical characters come to the fore. Character obtained at lower rates can be best appreciated in lagers or pilsners, while the grapefruit and tropical flavors can be used to offset robust malt and yeast characters
Used for: Ales, Lagers, Pilsners
Aroma: tropical, subtle hints of star anise, sweet and floral, with lemon, grapefruit, apricot, and melon. 
Substitutions: Galaxy
Storage: Unknown
13.3-16.3% AA / 4-7.8% Beta

name: Endeavour
notes: Bred at Wye Hops in the UK as a cross between Cascade and a hedgerow hop.  A wonderful, citrusy hedgerow hop with complex blackcurrant, loganberry and spicy notes as well as grapefruit and lime flavor.  Gentler than cascade.  Substitutes: Cascade

name: Equinox (HBC 366)
notes:
A pronounced aroma profile with citrus, tropical fruit, floral and herbal characteristics. Specific descriptors include lemon, lime, papaya, apple, and green pepper.

Used for: Experimental Ale
Aroma: Exceptional aroma profile includes notes of citrus, tropical and pine 
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
14.4-15.6% AA / 4.6-5.1% Beta

name: Eroica
notes:
Used for: General purpose bittering for ales, porters, stouts
Aroma: Clean bittering hop, very bitter
Substitutes: Galena, Northern Brewer, Chinook
Examples: Blackhook Porter, Ballard Bitter

name: Eukanot
notes: Released in 2014 - has strong aroma character and a very high aromatic oil content. Aroma profile includes citrus, tropical fruit, fruity and herbal components.  Flavors include melon, berry, orange peel, lime, papaya, pine and fresh pepper components.

name: Eureka!
notes:
Notes: Offspring of Apollo and Merkur. Similar to Simcoe. Dual purpose. Good for dry hoping.

Aroma: Herbal, pine, mint, grapefruit rind, tangerine

name: Falconer's Flight
notes:
Proprietary pellet blend comprised of many of the Northwest’s most unique hop varieties and is perfect for any Northwest-style IPA.
Used for: IPA, Pale Ale, Experimental Ale
Aroma: distinct tropical, citrus, floral, lemon and grapefruit tones.
Substitutions: Unknown (Citra, Simcoe, Sorachi Ace blend?)
Storage: Unknown
10-12% AA / 4.4% Beta

name: Falconer's Flight 7C's Blend
notes:
A proprietary hop blend from HopUnion that includes 7 of the "C" hops along with a few experimental varieties.
Used for: Pale Ale, IPA, Experimental Ales
Aroma: Citrus/grapefruit character alongside fruity, spicy, and earthy notes
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
9-10% AA / 4.5% Beta

name: Fantasia
notes: A Barth-Haas Group product said to have a flavor/profile of cream and caramel.

name: Feux Coeur Francais
notes: Rare, high alpha hops from Australia with genetic roots in the Burgundy region of France.  It was adopted to the Victoria region of Australia and introduced in 2010.

name: Feux-Coeur
notes: Australian hop with genetic roots back to Burgundy France.  Fairly rare breed from Victoria.

name: First Gold
notes:
Dwarf hop with English Golding character
Used for: Ales, ESB
Aroma: Similar to other Golding varieties, spicy
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Crystal

name: Flyer
notes: A cross between a high alpha female breeding line and low trellis male. Released for trials in 2009.  A citrus hop with aromas of stoned fruit, liquorice, tracle-toffee and caramel with slight burnt notes.  Spicy, resinous, citrus and liquorice notes.

name: Fuggle
notes:
Traditional English-type aroma hop.
Used for: English Ales, ESB, Bitter, Lagers
Aroma: Mild, soft, fruity, spicy, woody
Substitute: Fuggle (U.S.), Willamette, Styrian Golding
Storage: Good/Very Good (70-80% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
3-5.6% AA 2-3% Beta

name: Fuggle, New Zealand
notes:
Fuggle is the classic English aroma hop and is often used in conjunction with Goldings. It can be used as a main boiling hop to impart a mild, soft grassy/woody floral aroma and is also used for dry hopping.

Used for: English Ales, Porter, Stout, English IPA
Substitutions: UK Fuggle, NZ Willamette, NZ Styrian Golding

name: Fuggle, Organic
notes:
As Fuggle (U.K.), only organic variety
Typical alpha: 3-5%. Organically grown Fuggle hops from the UK. Wonderful earthy, pipe-tobacco, floral character. Classic hop for any English ale.

name: Fuggle, U.S.
notes:
This classic English aroma variety has long been grown in both Oregon and Washington. It has a typical English aroma and contributes a balanced bitterness. Fuggle is very suitable for English and American-style Ales. Mild wood and fruit characteristics.

Used for: English Ales
Substitutions: Willamette, UK Fuggle, Styrian Golding

name: Fuggles
notes:
Used for: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers
Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma
Substitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette
Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

name: Galaxy
notes:
A high alpha, dual purpose seedless hops with a unique hop aroma.  It can be used either for bittering or as a late hop addition to provide a flavor of citrus and passionfruit to the finished beer.
Aroma: Intense, pleasant, unique.

name: Galena
notes:
Used for: General bittering hops for all beers
Aroma: Strong, clean, balanced bittering
Substitutes: Eroica, Northern Brewer, Cluster, Chinook
Examples: Catamount Porter

name: Gargoyle
notes: Gargoyle along with Ivanhoe are the first generation of California Cluster hops to be grown commercially in over 50 years.  Revived by Hops-Mesiter near Clearlake CA.  Similar to Ivanhoe but has a more citrus-mango bouquet.  Substitute: Ivanhoe

name: German Tradition
notes:
Close descendant of Hallertauer Mittelfrueh bred for high yield.
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Bock, some Weizens
Aroma: Medium intense floral and herbal (grassy) tones
Substitutes: Hallertau Mittelfruh, Liberty, Hersbrucker
Storage: Unknown
5-7% AA / 4-5% Beta

name: Gesho Kitel
notes: Brundo's aroma hops Gesho stems, gathered from the highlands of Ethiopia, are sun-dried and packed fresh. These aromatic sticks and stem flavor centuries old traditional brewing recipes for beer and Ethiopian honey wine. Acid content unknown.

name: Glacier
notes:
Genetic mix of at least 8 hops including Elsasser, Brewers Gold, N Brewer, Bullion, Early Green, and others...released in 2000.
Used for: Aroma
Aroma: Excellent, hoppy
Substitutes: N/A

name: Gold
notes: Daughter of Styrian Savinsjki Golding released in 2009.  Distinct aroma grown only in Slovenia.  Aroma of honey, oregano, basil, nettle and hay.

name: Golding, New Zealand
notes:
Mild, delicate sweet floral character

Used for: English Ales
Substitutions: NZ Willamette, NZ Styrian Golding, NZ Fuggle, UK East Kent Golding

name: Golding, U.S.
notes:
Mild and delicate with sweet floral characteristics. Bred in the US from east Kent Golding. Golding hops consist of a group of traditional English aroma varieties which have been cultivated since 1790. Several
selections now exist including Cobbs, Early Bird, East Well, Bramling, Canterbury and Mathon, some of which are now being grown in the U. S. All Goldings are recognized as having a most typical English aroma.

Used for: Bitter
Substitutions: Fuggle, Willamette, UK East Kent Golding, Styrian Golding

name: Goldings, B.C.
notes:
Used for: Bittering and finishing British ales, bitters, porters and stouts.
Aroma: Spicy, floral, rounded mild aroma.
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Fuggles

name: Goldings, East Kent
notes:
Used for: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales
Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor
Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings
Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

name: Green Bullet
notes:
Bittering hops from New Zealand developed in 1972
Used for: Australian-style ales and lagers.
Aroma: Floral, raisin aroma.
Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

name: Greenburg
notes: American hop variety from southern Idaho.  Fruity flavor with a touch of wood flavor.  Popular with microbreweries.

name: HBC 291 (Experimental)
notes:
As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion
Uses: Unknown
Aroma: Typically described as peppery, floral and fruity
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
11.2-13.1% AA / 5.1-6.1% Beta

name: HBC 342 (Experimental)
notes:
As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion. "High alpha variety with a pleasant aroma"
Uses: Pale Ale
Aroma: Mild citrus, tropical fruit and melon notes 
Substitutions: Unknown (Belma or Citra?)
Storage: Unknown
??% AA / ??% Beta

name: HBC 366 (Experimental)
notes:
As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion. "The fantastic aroma combined with the high high oils make this hop very unique"
Uses: Experimental Ale
Aroma: Exceptional aroma profile includes notes of citrus, tropical and pine 
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
14.4-15.6% AA / 4.6-5.1% Beta

name: HBC 438
notes: An experimental hop that is a cross between a neomexicanus and YCR 123.  It is sister to HBC 472 and has similar character.  Aromas include mango, coconut, grapefruit, lemon grass and wood.  Peachy stone fruit, pineapple., lime and herbal notes of cedar and coconut.  A disctinct hop.  Subsitute: HBC 472

name: Cekin
notes: Developed at the Hop Research Inst in Slovnia in the 1980's.  A cross between Aurora and a Yugoslav male.  Not grown in large quantities.  Pleasing and continental aroma similar to Savinjski Golding.  Substitute: Savinjski Golding or Aurora

name: Hallertau Blanc
notes:
Floral and fruity with passion fruit, grapefruit, pineapple, grape and lemongrass overtones. One of several new German varieties with bold flavor profiles, perfect for American-style Ales.

Used for: American style ale
Substitutions: N/A
Storage Unknown

name: Hallertau Magnum
notes:
German Hallertauer hybrid, widely used in Germany. Extremely appropriate for early boil additions.
Used for: German ales and lagers, bitters, IPAs, pilsners, pale ales, stouts.
Aroma: somewhat unnoticeable aroma; stable spicy flavor
Substitutes: Hallertau Taurus, Columbus, Nugget
Storage: Excellent (80%-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
12-14% AA / 4.5-5.5% Beta

name: Hallertau Taurus
notes:
Bred at the Huell Hops Institute in Germany and prided in its bittering qualities. The bittering is moderately abundant and this variety adds a pleasant aroma as well.
Used for: Schwawrz, Oktoberfest, Lager
Aroma: seasoned, flavorful, zesty character
Substitutions: Hallertau Magnum, German Tradition
Storage: Fair/Good (60%-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
12.3-17.9% AA / 4-6% Beta

name: Hallertauer
notes:
Used for: German Ales, German/US/Canadian Lagers, Wheat Beers
Aroma: Pleasant, mild spicy flavor, clean, neutral flavor
Substitutes: Crystal, Liberty, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Hallertauer Hersbrucker
notes:
Used for: German style lagers and wheat beers
Aroma: Noble, pleasant, clean flavor
Substitutes: Mt. Hood, Liberty, Hallertauer, Mittelfrueh
Examples: Wheathook Wheaten Ale

name: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
notes:
Used for: Continental Lagers, German Ales/Lagers, US Lagers
Aroma: Pleasant, assertive, mild herbal aroma
Substitutes: Hallertauer, Mt. Hood, Liberty, Crystal
Examples: Sam Adams Boston Lager, Sam Adams Boston Lightship

name: Hallertauer, New Zealand
notes:
Hallertauer variant with classic aroma and ability to retain clean taste. Bred from German Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
Used for: Australian Ales
Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Harmonie
notes:
With typical Czech aroma, Harmonie's finely balanced bitterness "persists" slightly longer than Saaz. Bohemie, released in 2010, is a similar Czech hop with traditional aroma.
5-8% AA / 5-8% Beta

name: Helga (Southern Hallertau)
notes:
Perviously known as Southern Hallertau. Bears almost no aroma similarities to it's European cousin. Very unique aroma with moderate bittering.
Used for: Austrialian and English-style ales.
Aroma: Ddelicate floral and subtle herbal aroma
Substitutes: Unknown (possible Nobel Hop variety)
Storage: Unknown
5-6% AA / 3.8-5.4% Beta

name: Herald
notes:
Dwarf variety bred at Wye College (mid 1990s)
Used for: Bittering of ales
Aroma: Strong, acceptable
Substitutes: High alpha English bittering hops

name: Herkules
notes:
A German high alpha cross variety, bred in Huell and released in 2005. Imparts robust, hoppy tang flavors.
Used for: hoppy German-style ales or lagers
Aroma: Spicy floral and hop notes, with hints of pine, lemon and black pepper.
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Good
13-17% AA / 4-5.5% Beta

name: Hersbrucker
notes:
Hersbrucker Hops is similar to the noble hop varieties with its low co-humulone level.
Aroma: Classicly spicy, herbal, with hints of citrus and stone fruit.
Used for: German and Bavarian style Lagers, Pilsners, Hefeweizens, Dunkles, and Bocks
Substitutions: Mt. Hood, Strisselspalt, Hallertau Mittelfruh, Liberty
Storage: Fair (55%-65% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
2-5% AA / 4-6% Beta

name: HopShot
notes:
CO2-extracted hop resin that can be used for bittering or late additions to boiling wort.  Primarily for use in boil.  Made from Columbus (or CTZ) blend hops.
http://www.northernbrewer.com/documentation/hopshot.pdf

name: Horizon
notes:
Good dual purpose hops derived from Nugget hops in Oregon (1970)
Used for: All purpose Ales, Lagers
Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Magnum or other high alpha hops

name: Huell Melon
notes:
Distinct fruit characteristics including honeydew melon and strawberry flavors. An excellent consideration for varieties not necessarily associated with typical hop flavors.

Substitutions: N/A
Storage Unkonwn

name: Idaho #7
notes:
Notes: Dual purpose, high alpha acid

Aroma: Tropical fruit, orange, apricot, pine.

name: Idaho #7 Hop Hash
notes:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

Idaho #7 has a black tea charcter and fresh herbal aroma.

name: Ivanhoe
notes: A revival of the old California Cluster variety.  It has a European aroma that is more moderate than Cascade and has citrus, piney and heady floral and herbal notes.  Substitute: Cascade or Cluster

name: Jarrylo
notes:
Notes: Underwhelming hop. Good if used in combination of hops with stronger flavors like Amarillo.

Aroma: Banana, pear, spice.

name: Jester
notes: Developed by Charles Faram & Co, a proprietary hop different than most UK hops.  Aromatic notes of tropical fruit, grapefruit, blackcurrent and Lychee.  A late addition or dry hop, but not recommended for bittering in the boil.  Closer to a New World hop style.

name: Junga
notes: A high alpha bittering hop from Poland similar in some ways to German Magnum but with a nuce aroma.  Derived from a Saaz variety.  Substitute: Nugget, German Magnum or Target

name: Kazbek
notes: From the Czech Republic, released in 2008. The classic noble spice of saaz, but with a earthy lemon peel tone.  Primarily an aroma hop for whirlpool or dry hopping.  Noble hop character but high oil content.  Similar to a very strong Saaz with notes of citrus and grapefruit.  Substitute: Saaz

name: Bramling Cross
notes:
Developed in 1927 from commercial Goldings and wild hop variety.
Used for: ESB, Bitters, Pale Ale
Aroma: Mild, fruity, currant aroma.
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress, Whitbred

name: Kohatu
notes:
Moderate aroma with lime and pineapple with traces of pine. Overuse can exhibit "dank" character.

Used for: Belgian Ales, Wheat Beer, Blonde Ale
Substitutions: N/A

name: Legacy
notes: Legacy has been cultivated in Washington state for over 50 years, but was registered and named in 2013.  It has some wild notes of blackberry, black currant, orange, grapefruit and florap and spicy notes.

name: Lemondrop
notes:
Notes: Good for citrusy IPA, APA, IPL, or Saisons. Should be used with a hop with more distinct flavor that would benefit from the lemon flavor.

Aroma: Lemony, floral, earthy, herbal, grassy, pine, pepper

name: Liberty
notes:
Used for: German style lagers
Aroma: Fine, mild, slightly spicy flavor
Substitutes: Hallertau, Mt Hood, Crystal
Examples: Pete's Wicked Lager

name: Liberty, New Zealand
notes: Mild and spicy, subtle lemon and citrus. Used in many styles. Contributes good bitterness in the beginning of the boil and an aroma of grapes, peaches, and vanilla at the end of the boil. Derived from Hallertau Mittlefruh.

name: Loral
notes: Released in 2016, Loral HBC 291 has a noble heritage and crosses old world and new world aromatics.  Pleasant aroma including floral, pepper, lemon citrus and dark fruit notes.  Suitable for many beer styles.

name: Lublin
notes:
Version of Saaz grown in Poland - also called "Lubelski"
Used for: Bohemian lagers and Pilsners
Aroma: Noble, mild flavor similar to Saaz
Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger

name: Lublin (Lubelski)
notes:
Lublin, also called "Lubelski", was bred from Saaz and carries with it many of the same characteristics.
Used for: Bohemian lagers and Pilsners
Aroma: Noble, mild flavor similar to Saaz
Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger, Sterling
Storage: Good (70%-75% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
3-5% AA / 2.5-4% Beta

name: Magnum
notes:
High-alpha hop with clean, neutral bitterness. Can be used in almost any recipe.
Used for: Ale, Lager, Stout, hefeweizen, IPA, Bitter
Aroma: No distinctive aroma characteristics
Substitutions: German Magnum, CTZ, Nugget
Storage: Excellent/Very good (80%-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
10-14% AA / 4.5-7% Beta

name: Mandarina Bavaria
notes:
One of four new varieties released to German growers in 2012. Shares characteristics of its mother, Cascade, but fruitier and more herbal.
Used for: American pale ale, lager (as late hop)
Aroma: Distinct tangerine and citrus flavors
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
7-10% AA / 4-7% Beta

name: Marynka
notes: A widely produced Polish hop from the Lublin area.  Offspring of Brewer's Gold registered in 1988.  Excellent flavor profile.  Used primarily for bittering though it also features earthy, herbal flavors and aromas.

name: Mathon White
notes:
A very old varitety which may have been bred from Farnham Whitebine or Caturbury Whitebine like Goldings was.  A pleasant aroma similar to Goldings.  Goes well in most any English style.
Substitute: Kent Goldings or Bramling

name: Medusa
notes: A native hop of Colorado and New Mexico that is literally an entirely different species - humulus lupulus neomexicanus from most hops.  Strong flavor and aroma character of guava, melon, apricot, and citrus fruit.  Excellent in IPAs as whirlpool or dry hop addition.

name: Brewer's Gold
notes:
Primarily a bittering hop and commonly used in lighter style ales, although it works well in lagers.
Used for: English ales, German styles, farmhouse ales.
Aroma: Bittering hop with neutral aroma character, spice noted to its flavor and aroma
Substitutes: Northdown, Northern Brewer (Germany), Galena, Bullion, Chinnok, Cascade (U.S.)
Storage: Fair (60-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
7-10% AA / 3.5-4.5% Beta

name: Meridian
notes: Grown primarily in Willamette Valley - a unique variety with crisp flavors of lemon, mixed berry and tropical fruit.  Complements many other hop flavors very well.  Some notes of nectarine, apricots, with some pine. Use in: Belgians, IPAs, Blondes.  Substitute: Citra, Glacier, Centennial

name: Millenium
notes:
Originally developed as part of the Haas breeding program in the US, Millenium entered production in 2000.  It is a very high alpha hops used for bittering.
Aroma: Mild, herbal
Substitutes: Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus and Nugget

name: Merkur (Hallertauer Merkur)
notes:
Sometimes called Hallertauer Merkur, this variety was bred from a cross between Hallertaur Magnum and variety 81/8/13 from the Hull Hops Research Institute.  Mostly used for bittering qualities, appropriate for early to mid additions.
Aroma: Strong earthy, floral and citrus impressions
Substitutions: Maganum (U.S.), Hallertau Magnum
Storage: Fair/Good (60%-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
12-16.2% AA / 5.1% Beta

name: Monroe
notes: A new hop variety from Barth-Haas group.  Only 2.5% apha but a fairly high oil content.  Mild and smooth, full of red aromas including raspberry notes and orange syrup.

name: Kirin II
notes: A Japenese hop that grew from Japan's decision to reduce hop imports.  Grown domestically in Japan under government contract.  Developed by Kirin Brewery, it is a direct descendant of Saaz and White Vine.

name: Motueka
notes:
Flexible hop developed from Saaz.  Has noble character and aroma, lemon and lime tones, balanced bitterness, and unique flavor.

Used for: Lagers, Belgian Ales and Bohemian Pilsner.  
Substitutions: Saaz, Sterling

name: Moutere
notes:
Formerly called 'Brooklyn'.  A high alpha hop with distinctive tropical, grapefruit and passion fruit characters. Developed from Southern Cross.

Used for: IPAs
Substitutions: N/A

name: Mt. Hood
notes:
Used for: European Lagers, finishing
Aroma: Mild with a clean aroma, neutral flavor. Somewhat pungent.
Substitutes: Hallertauer, Liberty, Crystal

name: Mt. Rainier
notes:
Complex parentage, including Hallertau, Galena, and Fuggle. HopUnion has stated this hop was only bred thru 2010.
Used for: Lager
Aroma: Excellent floral and noble aromas, with citrus and licorice tones.
Substitutions: Hallertau, Fuggle
Storage: Unknown
5-8.1% AA / 5-7% Beta

name: Multihead
notes: MultiHead is a neomexicanus breed native to New Mexico and is so named because of its tendency to produce dual cones. It is a unique hop in the industry and in brewing features a heady, floral aroma and some citrus elements.

name: Nelson Sauvin
notes:
Triploid variety bred from "Smoothcone" released in 2000.  Oil profile said to taste like "fresh crushed gooseberries" similar to Sauvignon Blanc, giving it its name.  Very fruity, citrusy - use in moderation.  
Used for: Pale ale, Super Premiums.  
Substitutes: None

name: Neo1
notes: Another neomexicanus breed and native of New Mexico.  A high percent of limonene and linalool gives this hop a distinctive strong lemon-citrus character.  Sister to Amallia.

name: Newport
notes:
High alpha hops released in 2002 as a potential replacement for Galena.  Note that these hops have a large alpha range of 9.8%-17% so check the package!  Fairly pungent.
Used for: Primarily used for bittering in ales, stouts, barley wine.  
Substitutes: Galena

name: Northdown
notes:
Variation of Northern Brewers hops grown in England.
Used for: Bittering in English ales
Aroma: Good bittering, flavor and aroma
Substitutes: Northern Brewer

name: Northern Brewer
notes:
Also called Hallertauer Northern Brewers
Used for: Bittering and finishing both ales and lagers of all kinds
Aroma: Fine, dry, clean bittering hop.  Unique flavor.
Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Hallertauer
Examples: Anchor Steam, Old Peculiar,

name: Nugget
notes:
Used for: Bittering hops for ales
Aroma: Strong bittering, heavy, herbal aroma, spicy
Substitutes: Chinook
Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter

name: Olympic
notes:
Olympic is a high alpha hops released by Washington Agricultural Expt Station in 1983.  Heritage is from Brewers Gold and Fuggles.
Aroma: Spicy, citrus aroma
Substitutes: Brewers Gold

name: Opal
notes:
New variety from the hop research center in Hull.
Used for: Aroma hops in continental styles
Aroma: High aroma hops with hints of spice and subtle citrus.
Substitutes: Unknown

name: Orbit
notes: Selected from a NZ hop breeding program, available in limited quantities.  Resinous, piney, aromatic and some notes of tropical fruit.  Some variation from year to year due to varieties selected.

name: Melba
notes: Called the "Dame of Hops", Melba is a dual purpose hop from Australia's Ellerslie Hop Estate.  It has a high oil content and moderate alpha acid making it suitable for late and dry hop additions.  Adds a spicy bitterness. Aromatics of passion fruit, grapefruit, and citrus.  Comparable to Galaxy.

name: Mosaic (HBC 369)
notes:
Available in quantity for the first time after 2012 harvest. Still known to many as HBC 369. A daughter of Simcoe crossed with a Nugget derived male. An excellent aroma variety.
Used for: Ales, IPA, Experimental Ales
Aroma: Rich in mango, lemon, citrus, pine, and notably, blueberry.
Substitutes: Unknown
Storage: Good (25% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
11-13.5% AA / 3.2-3.9% Beta

name: Pacific Gem
notes:
High alpha smoothcone cross developed at DSIR in 1987.
Used for: Bittering - produces a cask-oak woody flavor.
Aroma: Pleasant - some blackberry aroma.
Substitutes: Bullion

name: Pacific Hallertau (aka Pacifica)
notes:
Hallertau variant which produces a typical Mittelfruh aroma combined with smooth bouquet and mild buttery flavor notes; typical of the flavor achieved in classic European lagers
Used for: Australian Ales, European lager
Aroma: Clean, floral with slight cinnamon-like spiciness. Orange marmalade and citrus aroma notes when used in late addition.  Soft finish if used in bittering.
Substitutes: Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfruh, Liberty, Mt. Hood
Storage: Good/Very Good
5-6% AA / 5.5-6.2% Beta

name: Pacific Sunrise
notes: A bittering hop released by Hort Research in 2000.  limited production.  A pleasant piney aroma.  Cross between a California Late Cluster, Fuggle and New Zealand male plant.

name: Hallertau
notes:
This traditional German land-race variety has limited acreage in the U.S. 
Used for: lager, pilsner, bock, wheat, Munich Helles, or Belgian style.
Aroma: considered mild, pleasant, and slightly flowery & spicy.
Substitutions: Liberty, German Hallertau, German Tradition
Storage: Fair (50-60% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
3.5-5.5% AA / 3.5-5.5% Beta

name: Pacifica
notes:
Aroma hop developed from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh in New Zealand (1994).  Blend of old and new world taste including Orange marmalade and citrus aroma notes when used in late addition.  Soft finish if used in bittering.  
Substitutes: Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Palisade
notes:
Also called YCR-4, Palisade is an aroma variety bread by Yakima Chief Ranches.  It has both aromatic and moderate bittering properties.  
Substitutes: Willamette

name: Pekko
notes:
Notes: Any style that coud incorporate Saaz could use Pekko.

Aroma: Floral, mint, herbal, citrus

name: Perle
notes:
Perle has a spciy character, and the aroma is moderate and pleasing. Commonly compared to Hallertau Mittlefruh.
Used for: German ales, lagers, Plisner, Alt, Maisbier, Dunkle, Kolsch
Aroma: Delicate floral and fruity tones
Substitutes: Northern Brewer, Perle (U.S.), Hallertau Mittelfruh, Hallertau Aroma
Storage: Good
6-10% AA / 2.5-5% Beta

name: Perle, U.S.
notes:
Bred from English Northern Brewer. Slightly spicy with herbal and floral characteristics.

Used for: Stout
Substitutions: Northern Brewer, German Northern Brewer, German Perle

name: Phoenix
notes:
Seedling derived from Wye Yoeman.
Used for: Ales
Aroma: Similar to Wye Challenger hops
Substitutes: Challenger, East Kent Golding, Northdown

name: Pilgrim
notes:
New variety from Wye College in 2001.  High Selinene content.
Used for: Bittering
Substitutes: N/A

name: Pioneer
notes:
Bred from Wye Omega at Wye College in the UK
Used for: ESB, English Ales
Aroma: Mild English hop aroma
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings

name: Pilot
notes:
A very new hops introduced in 2002 by Charles Faram & Co Ltd.  Mild herbal flavor with lemon hints and fresh mowed grass flavor.  
Used for: Primarily for bittering in APAs.  
Rare.

name: Polaris
notes:
Very high alpha and stunninly high oil content. Its aroma variously described as "ice candy", eucalyptus, peppermint, and citrus. A variety with bold taste and differentiating flavor.
Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pale Ales, IPA
Aroma: Intense floral and pleasant mint tones
Substitutes: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
19-23% AA / 5-7% Beta

name: Premiant
notes:
A cross between Czech aroma and bittering varieties.  Dual purpose though its aroma is not as strong as some other Czech hops.  Use in beers where a moderate hoppy aroma is needed.  
Used for: Moderate ales, lagers 
Substitutes: Saaz

name: Pride of Ringwood
notes:
Used for: General purpose bittering hops for Australian beers
Aroma: Moderate citric aroma, clean bittering flavor
Substitutes: Cluster, Galena

name: Progress
notes:
Used for: Bittering and aroma in English Ales
Aroma: Similar to Fuggles, aromatic, slightly sweet
Substitutes: Fuggles

name: Rakau (Alpharoma)
notes:
Previously known as Alpharoma. Suited for new world styles where brash fruit character and big but well constructed bitterness is desired. Has been compared to Nelson Sauvin as a "flavor hop".
Used for: Pale Ale, IPA, Lager
Aroma: Tropical fruit, passion fruit, apricot/peach
Substitutions: Amarillo, Summit
Storage: Good
10-11% AA / 4.6-6% Beta

name: Relax
notes: From Barth-Haas group - originally bred for tea and not beer.  Only 0.25% alpha acid and a huge beta acid punch and high oil content.  Use in whirlpool or dry hop for aroma oils.  Aromas of alpine meadows, lemongrass, hibiscus, cornflower and honeydew melons.

name: Riwaka
notes:
Formerly called B-Saaz, this was developed from old line Saazer hops in New Zealand.  
Used for: New world pale ale, regional pilsners
Aroma: Strong, hoppy. Some grapefruit and citrus character.

name: Rubin
notes:
The Czechs classify this as a bittering hop, but with its Saaz background it is genetically similar to European aroma varieties. Bitterness is not as smooth as Saaz, and it lingers longer.
Used for: Ales, Lagers
Aroma: Similar to old middle European aroma hops.
Substitutions: Saaz (CZ)
Storage: Unknown
9-14% AA / 3-6% Beta

name: Saaz
notes:
This traditional variety from the Czech Republic is grown on a limited basis in the U.S. A classic noble aroma that is famously used in Pilsners.
Used for: Bohemian-style beers, Continental lagers, Wheats, Pilsener lagers, Ales, Pilsners
Aroma: Seasoned herbal character
Substitiutions: Czech Saaz, Polish Lublin, Sterling
Storage: Poor
2-6% AA / 3-4.5% Beta

name: Santiam
notes:
Triploid aroma selection derived from Tettnang and Hallertauer (1997)
Used for: Lager, U.S. Pale Ale, Pilsner
Substitutes: German Tettnang, Spalt, Spalt Select

name: Saphir
notes:
A new noble breed as an alternative to Hallertau Mittelfrueh in an attempt to make it more disease resistant and commercially viable.  Similar in character to Hallertau varieties.  
Used for: Pilsners, lagers, Belgian whites.  
Substitutes: Hallertau Mittelfrueh

name: Satus
notes:
High alpha bittering hops from Yakima that is similar to Galena.  Of recent origin.  
Substitutes: Galena

name: Select Spalt
notes:
Bred from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh and Spalt in Germany.  Spalt character.
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Noble aroma hop substitute
Aroma: Very fine, spalt aroma
Substitutes: Spalter, Saaz, Tettnang

name: Serebrianka (Silver Hops)
notes: A Russian aroma hop that is actually a parent of Cascade. Not widely grown in the US, but still available in some areas.  Hints of black tea, herbs, tobacco with high humulene and fanesene content that contributes to pleasant continental aroma and taste.

name: Simcoe
notes:
High alpha bittering hops with good aroma characteristics.
Used for: IPAs
Aroma: Citrus and pine-like aroma
Substitutes: N/A

name: Sladek
notes:
Hybrid variety of Saaz origin with noble hoppy taste and aroma.  Generally recommended for middle-hopping about 20 min before end of boil.  Not a replacement for Saaz, but complimentary in Lagers.  
Used for: Lager 
Substitutes: Saaz

name: Smaragd (Emerald)
notes:
Perviously known as Emerald. A fine aroma variety with high bittering value.
Used for: Alt, Kolsch, or blond ale.
Aroma: Fine aroma, floral, fruity, spicy
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Fair
4-6% AA / 3.5-5.5% Beta

name: Sonnet Golding
notes:
Sonnet is a new hop variety bred from a Saaz variant that exhibited Goldings-like characteristics. It's used for aroma due to its low alpha acid content, and offers lots of floral notes.

Used for: English Ales, Belgian Style Ales
Substitutions: Saaz,East Kent Golding and Crystal.
Storage: Unknown

name: Sorachi Ace
notes:
Developed by Sapporo Breweries and used in their beers - has a Brewer's gold and Saaz heritage. Works well with Citra and Simcoe.
Used for: Saison, IPA, Pale Ale, Wheat, or other beer where lemon/citrus is desirable.
Aroma: Striking lemon charachter, a bold hop for bold beers.
Substitutes: Admiral, Cascade
Storage: Unknown
10-16% AA / 6-7% Beta

name: Southern Brewer
notes: Developed in the early 1970's to grow in South Africa after Golden Cluster was devistated by black root.  Primarily a bittering hop, not known for its aroma or unusual flavors.  Did not grow as well in limited sunlight but was bread to create Southern Promise.

name: Southern Cross
notes:
Dual purpose with "European" flavor - from DSIR in 1994
Used for: European flavor bittering/aroma
Aroma: Spicy, lemony, slight pine and wood flavors
Substitutes: N/A

name: Southern Dawn
notes: A relatively new South African hop used by some large breweries.  Resembles Southern Promise but with a different aroma profile.  Has a fruity, spicy aroma and is relatively neutral when bittering.

name: Southern Promise
notes: A high alpha hop bred in South Africa.  Created from Southern Brewer and a wild Slovenian male hop, it was bred to grow in limited sunlight.  Has a high alpha acid and cohumulone content giving it bright, smooth bittering qualities.  Can be dual-use with woody and earthy qualities.

name: Pacific Jade
notes:
High alpha bittering hops that delivers a bold herbal infusion of fresh citrus with some black pepper flavor.  Citrus aroma and flavor tempers ales and may be used as a finishing hops. 
Used for: Ales, lagers 
Substitutes: N/A

name: Sovereign
notes:
English dwarf hop, a daughter of Whitbread Golding.
Used for: ESB, other English Ales
Aroma: Can be intensely fruity; also produces softer flavors, including stone fruits such as peach.
Substitutes: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
4.5-6.5% AA / 2.1-3.1% Beta

name: Spalt Spalter
notes:
Available only from the Spalt region. fire aroma is unique despite genetic sililarities to Saaz, Tettnanger.
Used for: Traditional German beers, Altbiers, Lagers
Aroma: Fine/spicy, delicate, herbal, woody, floral
Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger
Storage: Poor
2.5-3.5 AA / 3-5% Beta

name: Spalter
notes:
Used for: Traditional German bittering and aroma hops, Altbiers, Lagers
Aroma: Mild, pleasant, slight spice
Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnang
Examples: Dusseldorf Altbiers

name: Spalter Select
notes:
Bred from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh and Spalt in Germany.  Solid replacement for Sazzer-type hops.
Used for: Lager, Pilsner
Aroma: Spicy, floral, and woody.
Substitutes: Spalt Spalter, Saaz, Tettnanger
Storage: Good/Fair
3-6.5% AA / 2.5-5% Beta

name: Sterling
notes:
Flavor is a cross between Saaz and Mt Hood
Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pilsners
Aroma: Herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus hints
Substitutes: Saaz, Polish Lublin

name: Sticklebract
notes:
High alpha hops from DSIR research first released in 1972.  Some of the same qualities as Northern Brewer
Used for: Dual purpose
Aroma: Pine-like with a hint of citrus
Substitutes: Northern Brewer

name: Strisslespalt
notes:
Aroma hops used widely in the Alsace area of France.
Used for: Pilsner, lager, wheat
Aroma: Medium intensity, pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Mt Hood, Crystal, Hallertauer Hersbruck

name: Styrian Aurora (Super Styrian)
notes:
Typical alpha: 7.0-9.0%. Moderate-alpha with powerful hoppy aroma, very versatile - try in US, Belgian, or English ales.
Uses: All Ales, some lagers
Aroma: Spicy, yet pleasant hoppiness
Substitutes: Styrian Golding, Styrian Bobek
Storage: Excellent
6.5-9.5% AA / 2.7-5.5% Beta

name: Outeniqua
notes: A high alpha bittering hop from South Africa.  Primarily a local hop, it features a well balanced oil profile and hoppy, punchy aroma.  Mother of the high alpha variety Southern Star.

name: Styrian Celeja
notes:
Hybrid cross between Styrian Golding, Styrian Aurora, and Slovenian wild hops. Aroma is orange marmalade like Styrian Golding, but with a noble component.
Used for: UK and Belgian ales or lagers.
Aroma: Floral, fruit
Substitutions: Unknown (Styrian Golding?)
Storage: Unknown 
3-6% AA / ??% Beta

name: Styrian Golding (Savinja Golding)
notes:
A seedless version of Fuggle grown in Slovenia. Popular in Europe and the United Kingdom.
Used for: All Ales and Lagers
Aroma: Delicate, slightly spicy, soft, and floral aroma. Similar to Fuggle.
Substitutes: Fuggle, Williamette, EKG
Storage: Very Good
4.5-6% AA / 2-3.5% Beta

name: Styrian Goldings
notes:
A seedless version of Fuggles grown in Slovenia
Used for: Bittering, finishing for a wide variety of European Beers. Popular in Europe and the United Kingdom
Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma. Similar to Fuggles.
Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

name: Summer (Summer Saaz)
notes:
Apricot and melon characters are more apparent when dry hopping.
Used for: Ales
Aroma: Subtle, light apricot and melon flavors
Substitiutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
4-7.5% AA / 4.8-6.7% Beta

name: Summit
notes:
High alpha variety bred by American Dwarf Hop Assoc.  Can be grown commercially on a low trellis.  
Aroma: Strong citrus, grapefruit notes.
Substitutes: Warrior, Millenium, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

name: Summit Hop Extract
notes:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Summit hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Sun
notes:
A very high alpha bittering hops from Yakima Valley, Washington
Used for: Bittering (intense)
Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Other very high alpha US hops

name: Super Alpha
notes:
High alpha hops released in 1976 by DSIR. European in character - clean crisp flavor and resin aroma.
Used for: European Styles, General purpose bittering
Aroma: Pleasant, resin like aroma
Substitutes: N/A

name: Super Galena
notes:
Super high alpha hops from Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006.  High alpha and beta content - comparable to Galena in bitterness and aroma profile.  
Used for: Primarily for bitterness.  
Substitutes: Galena

name: Super Pride
notes:
A high alpha variation of the Pride of Ringwood hop variety.  Features mild aromas, higher alpha content and low cohumulone levels.  
Used for: Primarily for bittering.  
Substitutes: Pride of Ringwood

name: Sussex
notes:
Aroma similar to Fuggle. Good, yet delicate, flavor retention. Pedigree is "a chance find". 

Used for: Ale
Sustitution: N/A
Storage: Unknown

name: Sybilla
notes: A varity from Poland which is primarily for bittering but has some good aromatic properties.  A mix of Lublin and Slovenian Styrian Goldings.  Good aroma hop with soft contintental character similar to a German Hallertauer, English Fuggles or Sterling.

name: Sylva
notes:
Formerly Southern Saaz. Displays what's considered the traditional hoppy (with cedarwood notes) and spicy character of Saaz. Mostly an option for Southern Hemisphere brewers but an interesting variation on Saaz.
Used for: Lagers
Aroma: Complex and subtle, floral and herbal characteristics
Substitutions: Hallertau Mittlefrüh, AU Helga
Storage: Unknown
4-7.3% AA / 3-5% Beta

name: Tahoma
notes: Citrus and lemon notes with cedar, pine, floral, pepper and subtle green melon notes. Daughter of Glacier that retains the very low cohumulone characteristic of Glacier with somewhat higher alpha acid content.

name: Taiheke
notes:
Formerly called 'Cascade, New Zealand'.  Flowers, citrus & spice with grapefruit the noticeable fragrance quite often. This medium aroma balances the low bittering value. Very popular hop among craft brewers.

Used for: Pale Ales, IPAs, Porters
Substitutions: Centennial, Amarillo

name: Tardif de Bourgogne
notes: "Late Burgundy" hops grown in small quantities in Alsace, France.  A mild European style aroma. Very limited quantities commercially.

name: Target
notes:
Used for: English ales and lagers
Aroma: Robust aroma and flavor
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings

name: Teamaker
notes: Developed by the USDA, Teamaker was released in the late 2000's.  It is a unique high beta, very low alpha breed sued in medicine and food industries as well as brewing.  It has very strong antibiotic properrties, and makes a tasty iced tea.  It imparts almost no bittering content, but has floral aromas.  Use as a late addition either whirlpool or dry hopping.

name: Tettnang
notes:
Used for: German ales, lagers and wheat beer
Aroma: Noble, mild, fine, slightly spicy
Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt
Examples: Sam Adams Octoberfest, Anderson Valley ESB

name: Tettnang (Tettnang Tettnager)
notes:
One of the four noble hops along with Saaz, Spalt, and Hallertau Mittelfrueh, a group of mainland European hops that are prized for their similar, delicate flavor and aroma profile.
Used for: German ales, lagers, wheat
Aroma: Noble, Mild and pleasant with balanced earthy, herbal and floral aroma impressions
Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt, Hallertau Mittelfrueh
Storage: Poor
2.5-6% AA / 3-5% Beta

name: Tettnang, U.S.
notes:
Tettnang is a traditional German land-race variety known for
its noble aroma that is pleasant and slightly spicy. It remains well established in the Tettnang growing region of Germany, and is also grown in Oregon and Washington. Americangrown Tettnang is reported to have slightly higher myrcene levels than its German counterpart.

Used for: American style ale
Substitutions: German Tettnang, Santiam, German Spalt, Spalt Select

name: Tillicum
notes:
High alpha and high beta hops developed though Haas breeding program and released in 1995.  Daughter variety of Galena and related to Chelan - so similar to both. 
Substitutes: Galena, Chelan

name: Tomahawk
notes:
Part of the Columbus/Tomahak/Zeus (CTZ) group of super high alpha hops.  Together these make up 1/4 of US hop acreage.  
Used for: High alpha hops used primarily for commercial bittering.  
Substitutes: Tomahawk, Zeus, Nugget, Galena, Chinook

name: Topaz
notes: Very high alpha hop variety from Australia.  Used for commercial production primarily for its high alpha acid content and high bitterness.

name: Tradition
notes:
Close descendant of Hallertauer Mittelfrueh bred for high yield.
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Bock, some Weizens
Aroma: Fine - similar to Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Liberty, Ultra

name: Triple Pearl
notes:
Pleasant and balanced with notes of melon, orange citrus, resin, spice and pepper. Stoarge stability unknown. Released in 2013 by USDA-ARS.

Used for: Pale Ale
Substitutions: Perle

name: Triskel
notes:
A cross between Strisselspalt and the male plant of the English hop variety of Yeoman. Contains many of the same characteristics as Strisselspalt, but with a more pronounced flavor profile. Strong floral, fruit and citrus characteristics.

Used for: Belgian style ale, Lager, IPA, Pilsner, Wheat
Substitutions: Ahtanum, Centennial, Chinook, Simcoe
Storage: Unknown

name: Tsingtao Flower
notes:
Accounts for about 65% of acreage in China, the Chinese version of American Cluster. 
Used for: Unknown (Lager?)
Aroma: Floral and Spicy
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Good
6-8% AA / 3-4.2% Beta

name: Ultra
notes:
Triploid seedling of the German Hallertauer Variety
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, wheat, finishing hops in ales
Aroma: Good to outstanding - some Saaz like qualities
Substitutes: Liberty, Hallertauer, Tradition, Saaz

name: Vanguard
notes:
Diploid seedling made in 1982, released in 1997. Hallertau Mitterfrueh parentage.
Used for: European lagers, ales
Aroma: Strong aromatic notes
Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Vic Secret
notes:
The clean, distinct fruit and pine characters of Vic Secret are best accessed by dry hopping or whirlpool additions. Late kettle additions have been found to impart a pleasant earthy character, but little fruit. Maintains very high levels of alpha acid so brewers may find it easier to craft the right balance in their beer by dry hopping. First commercial harvest in 2013.
Uses: Ales, Lagers, Experimental Ales
Aroma: Clean, distinct fruit and pine
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
14-17% AA / 2.2-2.8% Beta

name: Southern Star
notes: A high alpha hop from South Africa released in 2001.  Used primarily for bittering but features a spicy, tangy flavor and some aroma.

name: Styrian Bobek
notes:
Derived from a Northern Brewer and Yugoslavian male TG. Low to moderate alpha and earthy, slightly fruity aroma.
Uses: English Style Ales, ESB, Lager, Pilsner & Belgian-style Ales
Aroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma
Substitutions: Styrian Golding, UK or US Fuggle, Willamette
Storage: Good
3.5-7% AA / 4-6.1% Beta

name: Orion
notes:
Cross between Perle and an experimental variety
Used for: Bittering and aroma
Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Perle

name: Victoria
notes:
Hi alpha hops grown in Victoria, Australia.  It was created in 1976 and entered commercial production in the 1990s.
Used for: Primarily for bittering due to high alpha content.

name: Viking
notes: Developed in 1968 at Wye College in England.  A cross between Svalof and an English male plant.  High alpha for a British hop - the aroma is described as pleasant and hoppy.

name: Wai-iti
notes:
Strong citrus character of lime zest with fresh peaches and apricot. Used in both ales and lagers. Good for late additions and dry hopping.

Used for: Ale, Pale Ale, IPA.
Substitutions: N/A

name: Vital
notes: A high alpha hop from the Zatac breeding program.  High alpha and beta content provide a spicy aroma.  Used in some single hop pale ales with success.

name: Waimea
notes:
A high alpha acid, dual purpose hop with lots of pine and citrus characters. 

Used for: IPA
Substitutions: N/A

name: Wakatu (Hallertau Aroma)
notes:
Formerly called Hallertau Aroma. Similar to German Hallertau but higher alpha. Excellent Dual Purpose hop, rounded floral aroma with hints of lime. 
Used for: Lager, Pils, Bock, Wheat, Kolsch, Helles, Belgian Ales. 
Aroma: Restrained floral notes and freshly zested lime
Substitutions: US Hallertau, Liberty 
Storage: Good
6.5-8.5% AA / 8-9% Beta

name: Vojvodina
notes: A cross between Northern Brewer and a Golding male.  Mild, woody aroma with hints of tobacco and woody aroma.  Some noble character but more rounded.  Somewhat scarce availability.

name: Warrior
notes:
High alpha hops from Yakima Chief Ranches. Also called YCR-5.  Mild aroma and low cohumulone content - primarily for bittering.
Used for: Ales, stouts
Aroma: Neutral, clean, mild
Substitutes: Nugget, Columbus, Magnum

name: Whitbread Golding Variety (WGV)
notes:
Derived in England in 1911 from Bates Brewer. Some Golding characteristics, but lacking the full Goldings aroma.
Used for: Ales
Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy, slightly intense
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress

name: Willamette
notes:
Used for: Finishing American and British Ales
Aroma: Mild, grassy, floral, slightly spicy
Substitutes: Fuggles, East Kent Goldings
Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

name: Willamette, New Zealand
notes:
Mild, pleasant, slight spicy floral tones.

Used for: American and English Ales
Substitutions: US Willamette, Fuggles

name: Yakima Gold
notes: Aroma is mild and pleasant. An excellent general purpose variety with smooth bitterness and a pleasant aroma. Released by Washington State University in 2013.

name: Wye Challenger
notes:
Spicy, clean, citrus aroma with distinct herbal notes.

Used for: English Ales, English IPA, Red Ale, Bitter, Stout, Porter
Substitutions: N/A

name: Zeus
notes:
Super high alpha bittering hops developed in the Yakima Valley, WA
Used for: Bittering, intense aroma
Aroma: Aromatic, pleasant
Substitutes: Other high alpha hops

name: Zlatan
notes: A Czech hop released in 1976 and derived from Saaz.  Created in Zatac by the Hop Research Institute it attempts to maintain the character and aroma of Saaz.  It has a more mild bitterness and noble aroma if used late, as a whirlpool or dry hop addition.

name: Zythos
notes:
A proprietary pellet blend. Designed to complement existing IPA and Pale Ale hop varieties.
Used for: American-style Ale
Aroma: Distinct tropical (pineapple) and citrus tones, with slight pine characteristics
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
10-12.5% AA / 4.7-6.2% Beta
